showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.description: Order To Activation Geomapping of our completed orders for our prepaid mobile services. This includes NEW and TOPUP prepaid services.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.relevance: A visual representation of where our orders are being placed. Using this information the business can make more informed decisions about where to increase Retail Capacity and during what times this would have the most impact. For example, at the airport during arrival times of flights from certain countries that have a large prepaid purchase history.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where our activations / services are being purchased from. From a business perspective, this gives us a general understanding of where our customers are purchasing services and where we could potentially increase capacity for retail space.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions need to have a location. We then enrich that location data with a lookup that contains the latitude and longitude, and then we map this out with Splunk's geostats command.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.name: 02A Geomapping of Orders by Count
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields orderLocation | lookup prepaid_locations orderLocation | geostats count latfield=lat longfield=lon binspanlat=19 binspanlong=19

visualizations.title: 02A Geomapping of Orders by Count
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields orderLocation | lookup prepaid_locations orderLocation | geostats count latfield=lat longfield=lon binspanlat=19 binspanlong=19

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.description: Order To Activation Chart of our top purchasing countries.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.relevance: A visual representation of where top net-new purchases are originating from. Using this information the business can make more informed decisions about where to increase Marketing Campaignes and during what times this would have the most impact. For example, during Christmas in Western Countries, or during Chinese New Years.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where our net-new customers are from based on their Order Details. From a business perspective, this gives us an understanding of where our customers are from and how marketing or campaigns could drive business.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions need to be enriched with information about the customer. In this example a billing system, and regulatory requirements, have us record either a Passport or Federal ID for the customer. We then use this data point with each transaction and chart this.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.name: 02A Top New Prepaid Purchasing Countries
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields iDCountry orderType | search orderType="NEW" | eval iDCountry=upper(iDCountry) | top iDCountry

visualizations.title: 02A Top New Prepaid Purchasing Countries
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields iDCountry orderType | search orderType="NEW" | eval iDCountry=upper(iDCountry) | top iDCountry

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.relevance: A visual representation of what we sold over the specified time range. This example allows the business to make an informed decisions about what services are being sold over time. .
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.operationalize: This search gives us insight to what services our customers are purchasng based on their Order Details. From a business perspective, this gives us an understanding of what our customers want and how marketing or campaigns could drive business.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions needs have a ordertype field which must correspond to the Service Description of what is being sold.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.name: O2A Timechart of Ordertypes

visualizations.title: O2A Timechart of Ordertypes

showcase_cdn_search0001.id: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
showcase_cdn_search0001.help: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
showcase_cdn_search0001.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a total message size transferred per request, the content provider / identifier, and the status of the content. E,g., if the requested content is cached, or not.
showcase_cdn_search0001.operationalize: Having an understanding of how much content is being delivered by CDN Caches allows us to understand how to better operationalize our networks for Content Delivery.
showcase_cdn_search0001.relevance: This analyzes your CDN logs and gives you an understanding of the amount of your content that is being accessed from Cached Content based on number of requests.
showcase_cdn_search0001.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
showcase_cdn_search0001.description: Ratio of Requests that are accessing content from Cache Network, and not directly from the central content provider.
showcase_cdn_search0001.name: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
showcase_cdn_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes cached cp | stats count values(messageBytes) AS totalBytes by _time cp cached | stats sum(count) AS totalRequests sum(totalBytes) as totalBytes by cached  | stats sum(totalRequests) as totalRequested sum(eval(totalRequests*if(cached=="true",1,0))) as "cached" | eval cacheRequestedHitRatio=round(cached/totalRequested * 100, 2) | fields cacheRequestedHitRatio

examples.name: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes cached cp | stats count values(messageBytes) AS totalBytes by _time cp cached | stats sum(count) AS totalRequests sum(totalBytes) as totalBytes by cached  | stats sum(totalRequests) as totalRequested sum(eval(totalRequests*if(cached=="true",1,0))) as "cached" | eval cacheRequestedHitRatio=round(cached/totalRequested * 100, 2) | fields cacheRequestedHitRatio

showcase_cdn_search0002.id: Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
showcase_cdn_search0002.description: Ratio of Traffic that is accessing the Cache, and not directly from the central content provider.
showcase_cdn_search0002.relevance: This search shows us what ratio of our traffic is accessing cached content.
showcase_cdn_search0002.operationalize: This search gives us insight to what ratio of the traffic for our Content is coming from our Caches. Based on the value of this, the business can make informed decisions about where to increase, or decrease, caching capabilities.
showcase_cdn_search0002.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a total message size transferred per request, and the status of the content. E,g., if the requested content is cached, or not.
showcase_cdn_search0002.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0002.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
showcase_cdn_search0002.name: Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
showcase_cdn_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes cached | stats sum(messageBytes) as "totalBytes", sum(eval(messageBytes * if(cached=="true",1,0))) as "cachedBytes" | eval cacheTrafficHitRatio=round(cachedBytes/totalBytes*100,2) | fields cacheTrafficHitRatio

examples.name: Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes cached | stats sum(messageBytes) as "totalBytes", sum(eval(messageBytes * if(cached=="true",1,0))) as "cachedBytes" | eval cacheTrafficHitRatio=round(cachedBytes/totalBytes*100,2) | fields cacheTrafficHitRatio

showcase_cdn_search0003.id: Total Number of Requests for the CDN Network(s)
showcase_cdn_search0003.description: Total number of requests that are CDN is serving up, including both cached and non-cached content.
showcase_cdn_search0003.relevance: This search shows us the total number of requests that our CDN is serving up.
showcase_cdn_search0003.operationalize: This search gives us an understanding of the total number of request our CDN is historically serving. Based on the value of this, the business can make informed decisions about when and where to increase, or decrease, caching capabilities.
showcase_cdn_search0003.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a total message size transferred per request, and the status of the content. E,g., if the requested content is cached, or not.
showcase_cdn_search0003.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0003.name: CDN Total Number of Requests

visualizations.title: CDN Total Number of Requests
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval _time=strptime(_time, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | stats count

showcase_cdn_search0004.description: The total amount of traffic served by the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0004.relevance: This example shows us the total amount of data transferred out the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0004.operationalize: This search gives us an understanding of the total amount of traffic our CDN has served. Based on the value of this, the business can make informed decisions about when and where to increase, or decrease, caching capabilities.
showcase_cdn_search0004.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a total message size transferred per request.
showcase_cdn_search0004.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0004.name: CDN Total Amount of Traffic
showcase_cdn_search0004.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes | stats sum(messageBytes) as totalTrafficBytes | eval totalTrafficGBytes=totalTrafficBytes/pow(10,9) | fields totalTrafficGBytes

visualizations.title: CDN Total Amount of Traffic
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes | stats sum(messageBytes) as totalTrafficBytes | eval totalTrafficGBytes=totalTrafficBytes/pow(10,9) | fields totalTrafficGBytes

showcase_cdn_search0005.id: CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0005.description: The total number of Errors Over Time for the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0005.relevance: This example shows us the total number of errors over time for the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0005.operationalize: This search gives us an understanding of the total number of HTTP errors to our CDN. Where these values are high gives us insight to where we maybe having hardware, software, or general content delivery issues. Being able to identify these quickly, and resolve the problems is great for business.
showcase_cdn_search0005.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a http response code. At a minimum you need http response codes 400+.
showcase_cdn_search0005.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0005.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0005.name: CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time messageBytes cached cp status | eval statusFailed=if(status >= 400, 1, 0) | search statusFailed="1" | timechart fixedrange=false span=1m sum(statusFailed) AS "Error Events"

examples.name: CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time messageBytes cached cp status | eval statusFailed=if(status >= 400, 1, 0) | search statusFailed="1" | timechart fixedrange=false span=1m sum(statusFailed) AS "Error Events"

showcase_cdn_search0006.id: CDN Total Amount of Traffic Transferred Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0006.description: The total amount of traffic transferred over the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0006.relevance: This example shows us the total amount of traffic our CDN is using.
showcase_cdn_search0006.operationalize: This search gives us an understanding of the total amount of traffic within the CDN. Where these values are high gives us insight to where we may need to increase capacity, or perhaps increase content delivery pricing. Being able to identify these quickly, and resolve the problems is great for business.
showcase_cdn_search0006.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data and total bytes of data transferred.
showcase_cdn_search0006.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0006.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=CDN Total Amount of Traffic Transferred Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0006.name: CDN Total Amount of Traffic Transferred Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0006.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time messageBytes | eval trafficMbs=messageBytes/pow(1024,2) | timechart span=15s fixedrange=false sum(trafficMbs) as trafficMbs

examples.name: CDN Total Amount of Traffic Transferred Over Time
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: CDN Total Amount of Traffic Transferred Over Time
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time messageBytes | eval trafficMbs=messageBytes/pow(1024,2) | timechart span=15s fixedrange=false sum(trafficMbs) as trafficMbs

showcase_cdn_search0007.id: CDN Average Respone Time over Time
showcase_cdn_search0007.description: The Average Response time, in MS, of content delivered from the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0007.relevance: The average response time for content delivered in the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0007.operationalize: This search gives us an understanding of the average response times in the CDN. Where these values are high gives us insight to where we may have technical issues that need to be investigated.
showcase_cdn_search0007.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data and response time for each request.
showcase_cdn_search0007.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0007.name: CDN Average Respone Time over Time
showcase_cdn_search0007.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time responseTime | timechart fixedrange=false span=1m avg(responseTime) AS avgResponseTime | eval avgResponseTime=round(avgResponseTime,3)

examples.name: CDN Average Respone Time over Time
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: CDN Average Respone Time over Time

showcase_cdn_search0008.id: CDN Geostats of Requests by Location
showcase_cdn_search0008.description: Find out where our requstest are coming from and map the results with Splunk's geostats command.
showcase_cdn_search0008.relevance: This gives us a visual representation of where Requests for Content are coming from.
showcase_cdn_search0008.operationalize: Understanding where our requests are coming from allows us to make more informed decisions about capacity and planning for the network.
showcase_cdn_search0008.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data and an IP address of the requestor.
showcase_cdn_search0008.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0008.name: CDN Geostats of Requests by Location
showcase_cdn_search0008.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval _time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time requestClientIp | iplocation requestClientIp | geostats count latfield=lat longfield=lon

showcase_cdn_search0009.id: CDN Average Bandwidth Used Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0009.description: Find the Average Bandwidth being used for downloading content from the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0009.relevance: This gives us a visual representation of how much bandwidth is being used to consume content from the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0009.operationalize: Understanding how much bandwidth requests are using allows us to make more informed decisions about capacity and planning for the network.
showcase_cdn_search0009.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for the amount of data downloaded and the total time it took for the download to complete.
showcase_cdn_search0009.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0009.name: CDN Average Bandwidth Used Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0009.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(_time) AS _time | fields _time messageBytes netPerfdownloadTime| sort 0 _time | eval bandwidthUsedMbps = ((messageBytes/netPerfdownloadTime)*1000/1024/128) | timechart fixedrange=false span=1m avg(bandwidthUsedMbps) AS avgBandwidthUsedMbps

examples.name: CDN Average Bandwidth Used Over Time
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: CDN Average Bandwidth Used Over Time
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(_time) AS _time | fields _time messageBytes netPerfdownloadTime| sort 0 _time | eval bandwidthUsedMbps = ((messageBytes/netPerfdownloadTime)*1000/1024/128) | timechart fixedrange=false span=1m avg(bandwidthUsedMbps) AS avgBandwidthUsedMbps

showcase_cdn_search0010.id: CDN Average Last Mile Round Trip Time
showcase_cdn_search0010.description: This example gives us the average round trip time for the "last mile" of the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0010.relevance: For Telco's offering CDN, monitoring roundtrip times of "the last mile" is beneficial for content delivery.
showcase_cdn_search0010.operationalize: Understanding latency from the backhaul network to the "last mile", or Edge Servers / CPE, enables informed decisions about capacity management and planning.
showcase_cdn_search0010.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for the round trip time of what's defined as the Last Mile equipment. Typically this kind of data doesn't come from application logs, but from network monitoring tools or custom alerting solutions.
showcase_cdn_search0010.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0010.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=CDN Average Last Mile Round Trip Time
showcase_cdn_search0010.name: CDN Average Last Mile Round Trip Time
showcase_cdn_search0010.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time netPerflastMileRTT | stats avg(netPerflastMileRTT) AS avgLastMileRTT | eval avgLastMileRTT=round(avgLastMileRTT,3)

examples.name: CDN Average Last Mile Round Trip Time
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: CDN Average Last Mile Round Trip Time
visualizations.search:
| inputlookup cdn_general_operations 
| eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") 
| convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time 
| sort 0 _time 
| fields _time netPerflastMileRTT 
| stats avg(netPerflastMileRTT) AS avgLastMileRTT 
| eval avgLastMileRTT=round(avgLastMileRTT,3)

showcase_cdn_search0011.description: This example gives us the Edge / Region CDN's with the highest/slowest response times.
showcase_cdn_search0011.relevance: Understanding network behavior is a business priority. Being able to identify where Edge delivery is being impacted, or degredated, and remediate it is critical.
showcase_cdn_search0011.operationalize: If we can identify when Regions / Edges are experiencing high response times and degredation in services, we can better troubleshoot and remediate these issues. We can also use this to further understand regional user behavior and aid in forcasting network capacity.
showcase_cdn_search0011.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for the response time and ip data for clients accessing the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0011.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0011.name: CDN High Latency Edge Networks
showcase_cdn_search0011.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time responseTime requestClientIp | iplocation requestClientIp | eval City=case(City=="","Unknown",1=1,City) | eval Region=case(Region=="","Unknown",1=1,Region) | eval HostingEdge = Region." - ".Country | stats avg(responseTime) AS avgResponseTime by HostingEdge | eval "Average Response Time"=round(avgResponseTime,3) | rename HostingEdge AS "Edge Hosting Region"| sort - "Average Response Time" | fields "Edge Hosting Region" "Average Response Time"

visualizations.title: CDN High Latency Edge Networks
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time responseTime requestClientIp | iplocation requestClientIp | eval City=case(City=="","Unknown",1=1,City) | eval Region=case(Region=="","Unknown",1=1,Region) | eval HostingEdge = Region." - ".Country | stats avg(responseTime) AS avgResponseTime by HostingEdge | eval "Average Response Time"=round(avgResponseTime,3) | rename HostingEdge AS "Edge Hosting Region"| sort - "Average Response Time" | fields "Edge Hosting Region" "Average Response Time"

showcase_physical_search0001.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the User-to-Badges, Error Codes, and a Reader to Card locations.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search.
showcase_physical_search0001.operationalize: This search allows us to "monitor" a specific badge as it is used around monitored facilities. This could be used for a variety of reasons such as: Activity Logging, Compliance, Regulatory Reporting, and HR Related Requests.
showcase_physical_search0001.relevance: This search takes data logged from RFID / Proxmity badge readers, enriches it with facilties and logging information, and then shows activity for a designated badge.
showcase_physical_search0001.description: Track a badge on it's journey through a designated time period.
showcase_physical_search0001.name: Security Auditing - Badge Monitoring
showcase_physical_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId OUTPUTNEW firstName lastName emailAddress employeeId note officeId | search employeeId="25020002" | fields - badgereaderId,envAlarm,errorCode,powerStatus | eval fullName = firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId employeeId fullName officeId description status note | rename badgeId AS "Badge ID #" employeeId AS "Employee Number" fullName AS "Employee Name" officeId AS "Home Office" description AS "Card Reader Location" status AS "Read Status" note AS "Additional Notes.."

showcase_physical_search0002.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the User-to-Badges and a Reader to Card locations.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search.
showcase_physical_search0002.operationalize: Auditing of Physical Access is a requirement for many regulatory bodies and industrial certifications. Being able to associate ingress and egress traffic for designated rooms and zones, to badges, in near real-time expedites compliance and security.
showcase_physical_search0002.relevance: This examples searches RFID / Proximity logs for access to certain facilties and rooms. Reporting from this can be used for Security, Compliance, or Customer Reporting Requirements.
showcase_physical_search0002.description: Audit and Report on Room Access in a secure facility based on badge readers.
showcase_physical_search0002.name: Security Auditing - Secure Facilties Access
showcase_physical_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | search description="LV-DC-2-DC-003-*" | stats count list(description) AS Room list(status) AS Status list(badgeId) AS BadgeID list(employeeId) AS userId by _time | eval Personnel=if(match(userId,"-"),"Customer Card","Splunk Datacenter Staff") | eval Direction=case(match(Room,"-in"),"Ingress",match(Room,"-out"),"Egress") | eval Room=case(match(Room,"LV-DC-2-DC-003-"),"Secure Room - 3") | fields _time Room Personnel Direction | rename _time AS "Time" | convert ctime(Time)

images.label: Table Showing Access In and Out of Secure Room 3 of this facility.

showcase_physical_search0003.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_physical_search0003.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the User-to-Badges and a Reader to Card locations.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search.
showcase_physical_search0003.operationalize:
Security in facilities, especially Data Centers, is restricted and not only is there a need to control access but we also need to know who is accessing the facilities.

This example looks at where a badge has a high number of failures with an ACCESS-DENIED error. This could be indicative of a malicious user, or an employee with a badge problem. All of these should be immmediately actionable by facilities / security.
showcase_physical_search0003.relevance: In this example we look at how monitor abnormally high failures against a badge reader, or readers, over a time period. This can be indicative of a physical issue with a badge, or a security relevant situation where perhaps physical security is required.
showcase_physical_search0003.description: Let's find where access to badge readers has an abnormally high count within a 5 minute period.
showcase_physical_search0003.name: Security Auditing - Abnormal Failures
showcase_physical_search0003.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | eval fullName=firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId description fullName status | search status="ACCESS-DENIED" OR status="READ-SUCCESS" | streamstats count reset_on_change=true window=2 by description | search (count > 1) AND status="ACCESS-DENIED" | bin span=5m _time | stats count list(badgeId) AS Badge list(description) AS Location list(fullName) as Name by _time | where count > 1 | rename _time AS Time | convert ctime(Time) | table Time Location Badge Name

images.name: Wire_Transfer_Fraud_NewAccount.png
images.label: A particular badge having a bad day.

visualizations.title: Security Auditing - Abnormal Failures
visualizations.search: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | eval fullName=firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId description fullName status | search status="ACCESS-DENIED" OR status="READ-SUCCESS" | streamstats count reset_on_change=true window=2 by description | search (count > 1) AND status="ACCESS-DENIED" | bin span=5m _time | stats count list(badgeId) AS Badge list(description) AS Location list(fullName) as Name by _time | where count > 1 | rename _time AS Time | convert ctime(Time) | table Time Location Badge Name

showcase_physical_search0004.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_physical_search0004.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the Reader to Card locations and Error Codes. Matching the hardware codes to the environmental codes in the lookup is trivial, these are well documented by most hardware manufacturers.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search over your desired time range.
showcase_physical_search0004.operationalize: Being able to monitor badge readers and correlate environmental factors to specific events is what data analytics is all about. Being able to identify a power outage in a hallway and resolve this before a customer has problems is good.
showcase_physical_search0004.relevance: In this example we show a simple search that looks at environmental alerts coming out of our badge reader system.
showcase_physical_search0004.description: Most modern badger readers support various environmental triggers such as fire alarms, electricity failures, and backup battery failovers. This example shows how to search our RFID / Promixity badge system events for triggered environmental alarms.
showcase_physical_search0004.name: Security Auditing - Environmental Check
showcase_physical_search0004.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | fields _time badgereaderId description envAlarm errorCode powerStatus status | search envAlarm="FIRE" OR envAlarm="POWER"

showcase_physical_search0005.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the Reader to Card locations and Error Codes. Matching the hardware codes to the environmental codes in the lookup is trivial, these are well documented by most hardware manufacturers.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search over your desired time range.
showcase_physical_search0005.operationalize: Being able to monitor badge readers and correlate environmental factors to specific events is what data analytics is all about. Being able to identify a power outage in a hallway and resolve this before a customer has problems is good.
showcase_physical_search0005.relevance: In this example we show a simple search that looks at environmental alerts coming out of our badge reader system. We then perform from analytics on the data to determine an event duration and then format these in a way that can be presented.
showcase_physical_search0005.description: Most modern badger readers support various environmental triggers such as fire alarms, electricity failures, and backup battery failovers. This example shows how to search our RFID / Promixity badge system events for triggered environmental alarms and generate a nicely formated and human readable report that can be used for Compliance, Regulatory Reporting, Root Cause Analysis, etc.
showcase_physical_search0005.name: Security Auditing - Environmental Reporting
showcase_physical_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUT status | search envAlarm="FIRE" OR envAlarm="POWER" | sort _time | streamstats window=0 current=false latest(_time) AS previousEventTime latest(status) AS previousStatus BY description | eval duration = _time - previousEventTime | rename status AS currentStatus | fillnull value=0 duration | eval envAlarm=case(match(envAlarm,"FIRE"),"Fire Alarm Detected in Zone",match(envAlarm,"POWER"),"Power Event Detected in Zone") | fields _time description currentStatus duration envAlarm | rename description AS "Reader Location" currentStatus AS "Lock Status" envAlarm AS "Alarm" | convert ctime(previousEventTime) | where duration > 0 | rename duration AS "Duration of Alarm (seconds)" _time AS "Time Cleared" | convert ctime("Time Cleared") | table Alarm "Reader Location" "Lock Status" "Duration of Alarm (seconds)" "Time Cleared"

images.label: Power and fire issues all in one day?

showcase_subscriber_search0005.id: Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Failed Calls by Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.relevance: Identify where calls are failing, and which routes / gateways they are routing through.
showcase_subscriber_search0005.operationalize: This search gives us insight into where calls are failing and the path the system is routing the call through. Typically routing issues can be traced back to the underlying transit network, but with this information from our CDR logs, we can gain Operational Insight into where calls are encountering issues and proactively address these.
showcase_subscriber_search0005.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have the Destination/Callee, along with failure status, and the path used.

From here, we use stats to help correlate fields within the event and then format the results in a easily readable report.
showcase_subscriber_search0005.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0005.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.name: Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | table src dst dstCountryCode partyBiD disposition Description _time | stats count values(dst) AS Destination values(disposition) AS Disposition values(Description) AS Description values(_time) as Time by partyBiD dst | rename partyBiD AS "Routed Path" | table Time Destination Description "Routed Path" count

showcase_subscriber_search0006.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Mapping Successfully Dailed Calls
showcase_subscriber_search0006.relevance: Visual representation of where our succssfully connected calls are dialing.
showcase_subscriber_search0006.operationalize:
This search gives us insight into where our customers are calling the most in a visual representation.

From an opertational point of view, this view is a potential way to spot abnormalities in expected call behavior. And from a business persepective, we can use this information to potentially negotiate lower rates for this traffic, or perhaps raise our own prices.
showcase_subscriber_search0006.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee, along with succesful answer or busy status. (In this example, these two call statuses are what our metric is based on.) In addition to this, a country code is required in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the top command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0006.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0006.name: General Call Metrics - Geo Stats
showcase_subscriber_search0006.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | stats count by dstCountryName | geom geo_countries allFeatures=true featureIdfield=dstCountryName

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Geo Stats

showcase_subscriber_search0010.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the rare command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0010.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0010.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=General Call Metrics - Top Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0010.name: General Call Metrics - Top Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0010.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | fields src dst dstCountryName duration | stats count list(dst) AS dst list(dstCountryName) as dstCountryName by duration src | rename duration AS "Call Duration" src AS "Caller" dst AS "Called Number" dstCountryName AS "Destination Country" | sort - "Call Duration"

showcase_subscriber_search0011.id: General Call Metrics - Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Finding Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.relevance: Find our shortest call durations and their destinations. This could be used to identify fraud or abuse against the system.
showcase_subscriber_search0011.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where calls with the shortest duration time are going. From a business perspective, a high volume of calls like this to countries with high call tariffs might be indicative of malicious activity.
showcase_subscriber_search0011.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the rare command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.

showcase_subscriber_search0011.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | fields src dst dstCountryName duration | stats count list(dst) AS dst list(dstCountryName) as dstCountryName by duration src | rename duration AS "Call Duration" src AS "Caller" dst AS "Called Number" dstCountryName AS "Destination Country" | sort "Call Duration"

showcase_subscriber_search0012.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Finding Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0012.relevance: Find our shortest call durations and their destinations. This could be used to identify fraud or abuse against the system.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where calls with the shortest duration time are going. From a business perspective, a high volume of calls like this to countries with high call tariffs might be indicative of malicious activity.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the rare command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0012.name: General Call Metrics - Session Tracking
showcase_subscriber_search0012.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | table _time accountcode channel src dst duration partyBiD | rex field=channel ".*-(?<sessionId>\d+$)" | search duration > 0 | convert dur2sec(duration) AS CallDuration | eval CallDuration=round((CallDuration/60),0)." minutes" | stats count values(sessionId) AS SessionID values(accountcode) AS AccountID values(dst) AS DestinationNumber values(_time) AS DialTime list(CallDuration) AS CallDuration by src dst | lookup cdr_account_mappings accountCode AS AccountID OUTPUT accountName billingState | rename src AS SourceNumber | table AccountID accountName billingState SourceNumber DestinationNumber SessionID CallDuration DialTime

showcase_sa_search0001.description: WIFI AP Association - General Count of Valid AP Access
showcase_sa_search0001.relevance: Find out how many users are connecting to access points.
showcase_sa_search0001.operationalize: This search gives us the ability to monitor access points and the users that are connected to them. With this data we can validate that APs are available and have capacity. We can additionally monitor who is joining the APs and utilize metrics around that.
showcase_sa_search0001.howToImplement: This search requires time series data of access to the network access points.
showcase_sa_search0001.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_sa_search0001.name: WIFI AP Association
showcase_sa_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | sort - _time | timechart count fixedrange=false span=15m by apID

visualizations.title: WIFI AP Association
visualizations.search: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | sort - _time |  timechart count fixedrange=false span=15m by apID

showcase_sa_search0002.id: WIFI AP Geostats Access by Time
showcase_sa_search0002.description: WIFI AP Geostats Access by Time
showcase_sa_search0002.relevance: Find out how many users are connecting to access points based on Geostats.
showcase_sa_search0002.operationalize: This search gives us the ability to monitor access points and the users that are connected to them. With this data we can validate that APs are available and have capacity. We can additionally monitor who is joining the APs and utilize metrics around that.
showcase_sa_search0002.howToImplement: This search requires time series data of access to the network access points.
showcase_sa_search0002.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_sa_search0002.name: WIFI AP Geostats Access by Time
showcase_sa_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | geostats latfield=apLat longfield=apLong binspanlat=20 binspanlong=20 count by accessTime

visualizations.title: WIFI AP Geostats Access by Time

showcase_sa_search0003.relevance: Find our Average, Maximum, and Minimum connection durations per access.
showcase_sa_search0003.operationalize: This search gives us insight into the connection durations across the APs we're looking at. This can be good for capacity planning, troubleshooting, and security.
showcase_sa_search0003.howToImplement: This search requires time series data of access to the network access points along with a name mapping of the access points.
showcase_sa_search0003.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_sa_search0003.name: WIFI AP Access Duration Stats
showcase_sa_search0003.sampleSPL: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | sort _time | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(accessTime) AS accessTime mktime(accessDisconnectTime) AS accessDisconnectTime | eval accessDuration = accessDisconnectTime-accessTime | stats avg(accessDuration) as avgAccessDur max(accessDuration) as maxAccessdur min(accessDuration) as minAccessdur by apID | eval avgAccessDur=round(avgAccessDur/60,2) | eval maxAccessdur=round(maxAccessdur/60,2) | eval minAccessdur=round(minAccessdur/60,2) | rename apID AS "WIFI AP Name" avgAccessDur AS "Average Duration (Minutes)" maxAccessdur AS "Maximum Duration (Minutes)" minAccessdur AS "Minimum Duration (Minutes)"

visualizations.title: WIFI AP Access Duration Stats
visualizations.search: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | sort _time | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(accessTime) AS accessTime mktime(accessDisconnectTime) AS accessDisconnectTime | eval accessDuration = accessDisconnectTime-accessTime | stats avg(accessDuration) as avgAccessDur max(accessDuration) as maxAccessdur min(accessDuration) as minAccessdur by apID | eval avgAccessDur=round(avgAccessDur/60,2) | eval maxAccessdur=round(maxAccessdur/60,2) | eval minAccessdur=round(minAccessdur/60,2) | rename apID AS "WIFI AP Name" avgAccessDur AS "Average Duration (Minutes)" maxAccessdur AS "Maximum Duration (Minutes)" minAccessdur AS "Minimum Duration (Minutes)"

showcase_sa_search0004.id: WIFI AP Networks Users Connect To
showcase_sa_search0004.description: WIFI AP Networks Users Connect To
showcase_sa_search0004.relevance: Find our connection counts to our Access Points throughout the defined time periods.
showcase_sa_search0004.operationalize: This search gives us the ability to monitor access points on our network, or in specific geolocations. We can use this data for capacity planning and for security.
showcase_sa_search0004.howToImplement: This search requires time series data of access to the network access points.
showcase_sa_search0004.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_sa_search0004.name: WIFI AP Networks Users Connect To
showcase_sa_search0004.sampleSPL: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | sort - _time | stats count values(apInfoNetwork) AS apInfoNetworks by apID apInfoNetwork | stats list(apInfoNetwork) AS apInfoNetwork list(apID) as apID list(count) as Count | rename apInfoNetwork AS "Connected Network" apID AS "Access Point Connected" Count AS "Connection Count"

examples.name: WIFI AP Networks Users Connect To
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: WIFI AP Networks Users Connect To
visualizations.search: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | sort - _time | stats count values(apInfoNetwork) AS apInfoNetworks by apID apInfoNetwork | stats list(apInfoNetwork) AS apInfoNetwork list(apID) as apID list(count) as Count | rename apInfoNetwork AS "Connected Network" apID AS "Access Point Connected" Count AS "Connection Count"

showcase_sa_search0005.id: WIFI AP Access Users Top Cities
showcase_sa_search0005.description: WIFI AP Access Users - Top Cities Accessing Users are from.
showcase_sa_search0005.relevance: Find out where our top users are from.
showcase_sa_search0005.operationalize: This search gives us a general understanding of where the connected users are from. With this data we can provide Marketing teams with associated user metrics and look at ways to utilize this, perhaps through targeted marketing campaigns..
showcase_sa_search0005.howToImplement: This search requires time series data of access to the network access points along with enrichment data that contains associated enriched data such as age, billing location, and gender.
showcase_sa_search0005.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_sa_search0005.name: WIFI AP Access Users Top Cities
showcase_sa_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | sort - _time | where userCity != "UNKNOWN" | top userCity

showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.help: Lets look at Splunk Job Scheduler
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.operationalize: Words around how to operationalize things...
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.relevance: This looks at job scheduling in Splunk's internal logs....
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.description: You use splunk, but do you know Splunk?
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.name: Splunk Job Scheduler Status
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.sampleSPL: index=_internal earliest=-1y@y host=* sourcetype=scheduler (status="completed" OR status="skipped" OR status="deferred") | eval alert_actions = if(isnull(alert_actions) OR alert_actions == "", "none", alert_actions) | stats count by status | sort - count | eventstats sum(count) AS total | eval percent = round(count / total * 100, 2)." %" | fields - total | rename status as Status, app as App, user as User, savedsearch_name as "Report Name", alert_actions as "Alert Actions", count as Count, percent as "Percent of Total"

visualizations.title: Scheduler Status over all Time
visualizations.search: index=_internal earliest=-1y@y host=* sourcetype=scheduler (status="completed" OR status="skipped" OR status="deferred") | eval alert_actions = if(isnull(alert_actions) OR alert_actions == "", "none", alert_actions) | stats count by status | sort - count | eventstats sum(count) AS total | eval percent = round(count / total * 100, 2)." %" | fields - total | rename status as Status, app as App, user as User, savedsearch_name as "Report Name", alert_actions as "Alert Actions", count as Count, percent as "Percent of Total"
